text: my name is Brad bloomer I'm a climate
reporter at the New York Times the Paris
climate Accord was agreed to back in
2015 by 195 countries and it was seen as
the best most promising efforts day to
tackle climate change every country put
toward a mostly voluntary pledge for how
it planned to curb greenhouse gas
emissions and the idea was that over
time they would strengthen those efforts
by pressuring each other to ratchet up
their ambitions talking reviewing their
progress and basically engaging in
climate diplomacy president Trump has
already signaled that he does not want
the u.s. to be a leader on climate
change but pulling out of the Paris
climate Accord signals that he does not
want the country addressing this issue
at all and does not even want to
participate in future talks about the
issue the big question now is how other
countries respond to the u.s. pulling
out do they decide to redouble their own
efforts to curb greenhouse gas emissions
or does the agreements start to fray and
unravel without the United States and
this could go either way you've seen
countries like China France Germany
India all say they want to continue
addressing climate change even if the US
pulls out and they plan to continue
doing that so the Paris climate
agreement does not impose any actual
legal obligations on the United States
most legal experts agree that President
Roh plan to dismantle President Obama's
climate policies he would be free to do
so and still stay within the Paris
climate Accord accord within the
Republican Party an argument sort of
emerged that staying in the Paris Accord
did have these real legal risks that it
would interfere or possibly impede
present Trump's ability to dismantle
various climate policies right now if
you add up everything that countries are
currently doing they would not put us on
pace to avoid more than 2 degrees of
global warming which is considered the
goal countries would have to strengthen
their efforts over time if they wanted
to
that goal pretty dramatically in many
cases so with the u.s. out first it
becomes much harder to do without the US
which is responsible for that one-fifth
of global emissions and secondly if the
u.s. withdraws it won't be able to play
that role of pressure in other countries
to take more action won't be able to
play that role of pressure in China or
India to try to do more about climate
change than it already was
[Music]
